General course objectives:
General course objectives
Health technology is defined by the World Health Organization as the "application of organized knowledge and skills in the form of devices, medicines, vaccines, procedures, and systems developed to solve a health problem and improve quality of lives".

The overall aim of the course is to provide an overview and understanding of where and how physics is applied in Health Technology.

Health Technology involves a wide range of both classical and modern physics: mechanics (collisions and waves), thermodynamics,  electromagnetism (photonics), electrodynamics, relativity, quantum mechanics, atomic physics, solid state physics and nuclear physics.

Topics covered include magnetic resonance, ultrasound, optical sensing and imaging technology, as well as ionizing radiation.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
extract analyte concentration from optical absorption data.
determine particle size distribution from diffusion and optical scattering data.
select suitable, optics-based based method to extract information about specificity, concentation and size distribution of analyte in liquid solution.
calculate the evolution for coupled spin systems during magnetic resonance (MR) sequences.
derive the dependence of MR relaxation times on nuclear mobility.
explain the Overhauser effect and its applications for hyperpolarized MR.
explain ultrasound propagation and scattering.
explain properties of ultrasound fields.
design ultrasound arrays for high quality imaging.
explain the main type of interactions for photons, neutrons, electrons and protons.
explain the concept of kerma, absorbed dose and charge particle equilibrium.
compute the absorbed dose from given particle fluence.
Content:
The course gives an introduction to selected applications of physics in Health Technology:
(1) Optical techniques in the life-science lab. (2) Ionising radiation. (3) Magnetic resonance imaging. (4) Ultrasound imaging.
